sen.j: 鎌倉将軍邸について吾妻鏡に記録がありそれによると神殿・小御所・常御所・二棟御所・釣殿・侍所などでの構成がわかっていて、寝殿造の構成を引き継ぎながらも武家独自の空間構成がとられていることが伺えるし、釣殿の存在は、池泉庭園が造られていたのではないかと推測される。
sen.e: "Azuma Kagami" (The Mirror of the East) included descriptions of the residence of Kamakura shogun, and according to it, it is known that the residence was consisted of a shrine, Kogosho (the residence of shogun's heir), Nitogosho (the main place consisted of two halls), a tsuridono (fishing pavilion) and Samurai-dokoro (the Board of Retainers), and therefore, it is also known that it had a structure chracteristic of samurai residences, though inheriting the shinden-zukuri style architecture, and it is supposed that it was provided with a Chisen garden (Japanese style garden with a central pond and spring), because there was a tsuridono.

According to the descriptions of the residence of the Kamakura shogun in Azuma Kagami (The Mirror of the East), the residence consisted of a shrine, Kogosho (the residence of the shogun's heir), Tsune no gosho (a room for the Shogun), Nitogosho (the main place consisting of two halls), a tsuridono (fishing pavilion) and Samurai-dokoro, which shows that it inherited the characteristics shinden-zukuri style architecture while adding distinctive samurai aspects and the existence of a tsuridono suggests that there was Chisen garden (Japanese style garden with a central pond and spring).

sen.j: この時代の武士はその住宅建築の基本は平安貴族の生活の舞台であった寝殿造においていたが、生活活動内容は公家や殿上人などとは異なるものであるので、当然住居もそれに相応して変革が加えられているとみられる。
sen.e: In this era, the basic architecture of samurai residences was based on Shinden-zukuri style buildings that were main acting places of nobles in the Heian period, but the style was naturally modified for samurai residences corresponding to samrai's daily life style and activities that were different from those of Court nobles and tenjobito (high-ranking courtiers allowed into the Imperial Palace).

sen.j: そのほか、武家住宅の実態は今日でも十分解明されているとはいい難いが、およそは一棟あるいは棟続きの家屋の中に武士の詰所である遠侍や表座敷としての寝殿、対面所、客間として出居、公文所、居間などの諸室を配して周囲には堅固な塀や堀をめぐらすほか、小規模な家屋に対座して庭空間も寝殿造に比して小面積で、中門や車寄せの前庭が寝殿造の広庭にとってかわり、内庭が分化して鑑賞本位になっているとみられ、この基本構成は室町まで踏襲されている。
sen.e: In addition, although it cannot be said that details of samurai residences have been clarified sufficiently, such a typical residence was considered being made roughly in the following way and this basic structure was maintianted until the Muromachi period: In a building or connected buidings, various rooms, such as a tosaburai (tosamurai), (usually located near the gate in a worrior's compound and served as a reception office and guard headquaters), where samurai gathered, a shinden that was the main hall, taimen-jo (a meeting place where the relation between master and servant were confirmed each other), Dei (Idei) as a guest room, Kumonjyo, the Office of Administration and a living room, were placed, walls or moats were placed around the buidings, and the garden, which was placed facing the small-sized building and in front of a Chumon gate and entranceway and was smaller compared with that of a shinden-zukuri style, replaced the large garden of the shinden-zukuri style, making the function of the inside court mainly for viewing..

Additionally, although details of samurai residences have not been sufficiently clarified, such a typical residence was considered being made roughly in the following way and this basic structure was maintianted until the Muromachi period: In a building or connected buidings, various rooms, such as a tosaburai (tosamurai), (usually located near the gate in a worrior's compound and served as a reception office and guard headquaters), where samurai gathered, a shinden that was the main hall, taimen-jo (a meeting place where the relationship between master and servant was confirmed), Dei (Idei) as a guest room, Kumonjyo, the Office of Administration and a living room, were placed, walls or moats were placed around the buidings, and the garden, which was placed facing the small-sized building in front of a Chumon gate and entranceway was smaller, replacing the large garden of the shinden-zukuri style, making the inside court mainly for viewing..

Additionally, although the details of samurai residences are still not clear to this day, a typical residence consisted of the following up until the Muromachi period: In one building or a building with annexes, various rooms, such as a tosaburai (tosamurai), where samurai gathered, a shinden and taimen-jo (meeting place), where the samurai spent their days, Dei (Idei) as a guest room, Kumonjo (Office of Administration) and a living room, were placed with strong walls and moats surrounding the buildings, and the garden are was also smaller in comparison with Shinden-zukuri style, matching the smaller-sized buildings, and a front garden with a Chumon gate and entranceway was placed instead of the large garden typical of Shinden-zukuri style, and inside courtyard was divided into smaller sections mainly for viewing.
